Introduction

Lymphomas are a diverse group of lymphoid neoplasms (ie, arising from a cell committed to the B, T, or natural killer [NK] cell lineage), most commonly presenting as a mass within lymphatic tissue (eg, lymph node, thymus).  Hodgkin lymphoma (HL) originates from mature B cells and usually presents with painless lymphadenopathy (LAD).

Pathogenesis and risk factors



Unlike other hematopoietic cells, which begin and finish differentiation within the bone marrow, lymphoid cells originate in the bone marrow but complete differentiation in lymphoid organs.  For example, T cell precursors migrate from the bone marrow to the thymus, where they differentiate into mature T cells.  Similarly, B cells complete the final stages of differentiation in peripheral lymphoid organs (eg, lymph nodes).



In the lymph nodes, B cells are exposed to antigens and subsequently undergo somatic hypermutation and class switching in the germinal center (

figure 1
).  Although this process is essential for a diverse and effective humoral response, it is error-prone and susceptible to mutations that can predispose to malignancy.  In HL, a germinal center or postgerminal center B cell acquires mutations that transform it into a Reed-Sternberg (RS) cell, the hallmark neoplastic cell in HL.  These mutations allow for:



  • Aberrant cell signaling through disrupted regulation of certain signaling pathways.  NF-kB, a transcription factor that promotes B cell growth and survival, is constitutively active in HL.
  • Immune evasion through expression of certain cell surface membrane proteins (eg, PD-L1 makes T cells unable to respond to immune stimuli)
  • Increased cytokine expression through secretion of cytokines and chemokines that attract inflammatory cells (eg, lymphocytes, granulocytes) and create a favorable environment for RS cell survival.  Inflammatory cytokines also contribute to systemic symptoms associated with HL (eg, fever).


HL is distinguished from other lymphomas (ie, non-Hodgkin lymphomas) via a few key characteristics:



  • Characteristic RS cell within a background of reactive cells:  In other malignancies, the tumor cells comprise the majority of the tumor mass; in HL, the hallmark RS cells consist of only a tiny portion (usually <1%) of the overall mass.  Most of the tumor in HL consists of reactive inflammatory nonneoplastic cells attracted to the area by cytokines released by RS cells.
  • Predictable spread:  HL tends to arise in a single group of lymph nodes and spread contiguously in a predictable linear path from one node group to the next via the lymphatic channels.


HL is associated with a few risk factors:



  • Age:  bimodal distribution, peaking at age 15-35 and again at age >60
  • Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection likely increases the risk for the acquisition of mutations during the initial immune response.
  • Immunosuppression (eg, HIV, immunosuppressive therapy) likely contributes to immune evasion.

Clinical presentation



Patients with HL often present with:



  • Painless LAD:  particularly in the cervical, supraclavicular, and/or axillary chains.  LAD tends to be chronic (ie, developing over weeks to months), unilateral, and progressive.  Spread is usually via lymphatic channels to adjacent lymphatic chains; therefore, focal (rather than diffuse) LAD is usually seen.
  • Mediastinal mass:  present in 50%-75% of patients and can cause respiratory symptoms (eg, dyspnea, cough, orthopnea, stridor) and/or superior vena cava syndrome due to compression of adjacent structures (
    Superior vena cava syndrome
    ).
  • Systemic symptoms (eg, fatigue, weight loss, anorexia):  common; a minority will have B-symptoms (eg, unexplained fever >38 C [100.4 F] for 3 consecutive days, drenching night sweats, loss >10% of body weight over 6 months).


Hepatic and/or splenic enlargement (reflecting involvement of these organs) may also be seen.



A less common but classic presentation in adults is generalized pruritus and severe pain in areas of lymphadenopathy following alcohol ingestion (possibly due to alcohol-induced vasodilation within the lymph nodes, causing capsular distension).

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis for HL includes other conditions that can cause lymphadenopathy with systemic symptoms (eg, fever), including:

Infection



  • Viral infection (eg, EBV, cytomegalovirus):  likely to have acute and diffuse/bilateral LAD.  Initial screening labs (eg, serology, complete blood count [CBC] with differential) can identify the causative virus but if malignancy is suspected (eg, lymphadenopathy persists beyond 6 weeks), an excisional biopsy is necessary.
  • Bacterial infection (eg, group A Streptococcus, Staphylococcus aureus):  LAD is likely to be unilateral, like HL, but acute (ie, develops over days).  Tenderness, fluctuance, and/or increased warmth at the node suggests an infectious cause.  Microbiological testing (eg, bacterial culture from drainage, throat culture) may be considered to delineate the cause.  If bacterial infection is suspected, improvement following empiric antimicrobial therapy is confirmatory.
  • Secondary syphilis:  presents following the chancre (ie, ulcerative genital lesion) of primary syphilis, with patients developing constitutional symptoms and widespread, as opposed to localized, LAD.
  • Other infections (eg, tuberculosis, nontuberculous mycobacterial infection, Bartonella henselae):  present with chronic unilateral lymphadenitis.  Other clinical findings (eg, history of cat scratch, thin violaceous skin overlying the lymph nodes) may provide clues.  Specific testing for these infections may help distinguish these conditions.

Other malignancies



  • Hematologic malignancies (eg, acute lymphoblastic leukemia, non-Hodgkin lymphomas):  can be distinguished through other laboratory findings (eg, presence of blasts on peripheral smear, lack of RS cells admixed with inflammatory cells).
  • Metastatic cancer:  Metastasis to lymph nodes from other primary cancers, such as breast or lung cancer, can also cause lymphadenopathy, which can be distinguished by histology.

Rheumatologic disorders



  • Sarcoidosis:  is a granulomatous disease that can present with chest pain, cough, anemia, and eosinophilia.  It is usually characterized by hilar lymphadenopathy.  Serum angiotensin converting enzyme is elevated.
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE):  can cause fatigue, fever, and painless peripheral LAD in the cervical, axillary, or inguinal chains.  However, patients with SLE may have other features (eg, malar rash, arthralgia, serositis) that would not be expected in HL.


In addition, other conditions should be considered if a patient presents with an anterior mediastinal mass (eg, germ cell tumor, thymoma).  A biopsy is generally needed to distinguish these conditions.

Diagnosis



Clinical findings suspicious for HL (eg, presence of B symptoms, progressively enlarging localized lymph nodes) require further evaluation.

Laboratory evaluation



  • CBC and differential can be normal in early-stage disease.  Because of the inflammatory cytokines released by neoplastic cells, CBC may also show leukocytosis with eosinophilia along with anemia related to chronic inflammation.
  • Lactate dehydrogenase can be elevated due to rapid cell lysis.
  • Inflammatory markers (eg, CRP, ESR, ferritin) can be elevated due to inflammation.
  • Infectious workup (eg, EBV, HIV) can be positive given association with HL.

Imaging



Imaging (eg, chest radiograph) can show mediastinal masses (

image 1
).

Biopsy



If HL is suspected, an excisional lymph node biopsy (ie, removal of an intact node) is recommended to assess histology and architecture.  The presence of a RS cell (

image 2
), which appears as a large cell with abundant cytoplasm, multiple/multilobed nuclei, and prominent eosinophilic nucleoli, admixed with mostly nonneoplastic inflammatory cells (attracted to the area by cytokines released by RS cells) is a hallmark finding.  Immunophenotyping can confirm disease (cHL is usually positive for CD15 and CD30).



There are 2 main types of HL:



  • Classical Hodgkin lymphoma (cHL):  >90% of cases; subtypes include nodular sclerosis (most common) and lymphocyte-depleted (associated with HIV)
  • Nodular lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin lymphoma (NLPHL):  <10% of cases; characterized by lymphocyte-predominant (LP) cells (ie, "popcorn cells," an RS variant)

Staging



Following diagnosis, staging is performed for risk stratification and treatment planning.  Staging requires imaging (ie, positron emission tomography [PET] scan with 18-fluorodeoxyglucose [FDG], a radiolabeled glucose analogue) and is based on the number of involved lymph node sites:



  • Stage I:  single node region
  • Stage II:  â‰¥2 node regions on the same side of the diaphragm
  • Stage III:  node regions involving both sides of the diaphragm
  • Stage IV:  disseminated disease


The presence of other features (eg, B symptoms) are also included to stratify risk.

Management



Patients with HL are generally treated with combination chemotherapy (eg, doxorubicin, bleomycin, vinblastine, dacarbazine) with or without radiation therapy, depending on the stage of disease and response to treatment.  Because the clinical course of NLPHL tends to be indolent, surgical resection alone may also be acceptable for low-stage disease.



In addition, treatment with targeted therapies (eg, immune checkpoint inhibitors (

figure 3
)) may be considered in relapsed or refractory cases.



After completion of treatment, many patients with HL may have a residual tumor mass.  Because PET/CT can distinguish viable malignant cells from fibrotic tissue, they play an important role in assessing for metabolically active disease and determining response to treatment.

Prognosis



With current therapies, the overall prognosis for HL is favorable, as the 5-year overall survival rate exceeds 75%, even in advanced disease.  However, patients who undergo treatment for HL are at increased risk for multiple complications.



  • HL relapse can occur any time after treatment but usually occurs in the first 2 years.  Risk factors include higher stage, B symptoms, and/or presence of bulky tumors at diagnosis.  In the first 10 years after treatment, most deaths are related to HL relapse.
  • Second malignancy (>10 years) is the leading cause of death for HL survivors (eg, breast cancer, lung cancer, non-Hodgkin lymphomas) due to combined chemotherapy and radiation exposure.  This risk begins to rise 5 years after treatment.
  • Cardiovascular disease is the most common nonmalignant cause of death in long-term HL survivors.  Most cardiovascular complications are due to treatment-related damage to the heart muscle, valves, and vasculature.  Modifiable risk factors for heart disease (eg, control of hypertension and hyperlipidemia) should be addressed.


Other common treatment-related complications include pulmonary disease (eg, fibrosis) and hypothyroidism from chest radiation.  Survivors should receive routine monitoring for these complications.

Summary



Hodgkin lymphoma (HL) (

) is a malignancy arising from germinal center B lymphocytes.  It is characterized by the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells, neoplastic B cells with distinct features, surrounded by mixtures of reactive inflammatory cells and fibrosis.  Patients with HL typically present with painless adenopathy.  The overall prognosis of HL is highly favorable with current treatment, but patients who survive are at risk for significant complications related to therapy.
